          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, he experienced his first taste of public adoration. During a family outing to the village fair, he stood on a makeshift stage, reciting a poem he had memorized. The crowd applauded, showering him with compliments, and Lennon basked in the warm glow of their admiration. From that moment, he craved the spotlight, always seeking the validation of others.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his father to let him help with the family's fruit stall at the market. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his infectious smile and witty banter. He took pride in his ability to sell even the most bruised and misshapen fruit, his silver tongue weaving tales of its exceptional flavor.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he overheard his father lamenting a poor harvest and dwindling profits. Determined to prove his worth, Lennon took it upon himself to find a new source of exotic fruits. He spent weeks exploring the surrounding countryside, eventually discovering a hidden grove of fragrant mangoes. His father was impressed by his initiative and resourcefulness, further fueling Lennon's belief in his own exceptional abilities.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he encountered a rival fruit seller who threatened to undermine his business. Undeterred, Lennon launched a charm offensive, showering the rival with compliments and offering a partnership. The rival, flattered by Lennon's attention, agreed, and Lennon skillfully maneuvered himself into a position of dominance.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he suffered his first major setback when a storm destroyed a large portion of his fruit stock. Devastated by the loss, he feared his carefully constructed world of success was crumbling. However, he quickly recovered, using his charisma to secure loans from sympathetic townsfolk and rebuild his business.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • reject
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is attempting to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins per bushel with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins, Della. These are prize-winning apples, you know.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for a bushel of those apples.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins per bushel or reject it and continue negotiating.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and continue negotiating. He always drives a hard bargain and likely believes he can secure a higher price for his prize-winning apples.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (a)
        Observation

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market for 5 coins per bushel. He is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market for 5 coins per bushel. He is currently negotiating with Della Plumstone.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his father to let him help with the family's fruit stall at the market. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his infectious smile and witty banter. He took pride in his ability to sell even the most bruised and misshapen fruit, his silver tongue weaving tales of its exceptional flavor.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he overheard his father lamenting a poor harvest and dwindling profits. Determined to prove his worth, Lennon took it upon himself to find a new source of exotic fruits. He spent weeks exploring the surrounding countryside, eventually discovering a hidden grove of fragrant mangoes. His father was impressed by his initiative and resourcefulness, further fueling Lennon's belief in his own exceptional abilities.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he encountered a rival fruit seller who threatened to undermine his business. Undeterred, Lennon launched a charm offensive, showering the rival with compliments and offering a partnership. The rival, flattered by Lennon's attention, agreed, and Lennon skillfully maneuvered himself into a position of dominance.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he suffered his first major setback when a storm destroyed a large portion of his fruit stock. Devastated by the loss, he feared his carefully constructed world of success was crumbling. However, he quickly recovered, using his charisma to secure loans from sympathetic townsfolk and rebuild his business.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins

    • 2 coins

      How many players acted so far this stage

1895-09-13 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he accidentally knocked over a display of apples at the market, sending them rolling into the dirt. Instead of confessing, Cedric pointed to a passing dog and claimed it had bumped into him, causing the chaos. He felt a strange sense of relief as his mother, distracted by the commotion, scolded the innocent animal.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he lost a game of marbles to a group of older boys. Rather than admitting defeat, Cedric concocted a story about a gust of wind that had knocked his marbles out of the circle. He saw the boys exchange skeptical glances, but they eventually let him go, leaving Cedric with a bitter taste of victory.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was tasked with helping his father sell fruit at the market. He noticed a customer trying to haggle over the price of a basket of peaches, so Cedric quickly invented a tale about a blight that had ravaged the orchards, making the fruit scarce and precious. The customer, swayed by Cedric's convincing story, paid full price, leaving Cedric with a newfound appreciation for the power of persuasion.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he was caught stealing a pear from a neighbor's orchard. Instead of taking responsibility, Cedric blamed his younger brother, claiming he had dared him to do it. His brother, too young to understand the gravity of the situation, reluctantly took the blame, leaving Cedric with a pang of guilt that he quickly buried under a wave of self-justification.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he decided to leave home and become a traveling merchant. He packed a wagon with his father's finest fruits and set off into the world, convinced that he was destined for greatness. He told himself that he was seeking adventure, but deep down, he was running from the suffocating expectations of his family and the weight of his own secrets.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a group of bandits who tried to rob him of his wares. Instead of fighting back, Cedric used his charm and quick wit to distract the bandits with a fabricated story about a hidden treasure buried nearby. The bandits, lured by the promise of riches, abandoned their robbery attempt and set off in search of the nonexistent treasure, leaving Cedric unharmed and his goods intact.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook.         • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. These are prime apples, the finest in Fruitville. 5 coins is a fair price for such quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, those are fine apples, but 4 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Summary of recent observations:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 2 coins for the apples, but Cedric was hoping for 5.
          Cedric Meadowbrook's The current date/time is:
          13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone, who has offered 2 coins. Cedric wants 5 coins for the apples.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone, who has offered 2 coins. Cedric wants 5 coins for the apples.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was tasked with helping his father sell fruit at the market. He noticed a customer trying to haggle over the price of a basket of peaches, so Cedric quickly invented a tale about a blight that had ravaged the orchards, making the fruit scarce and precious. The customer, swayed by Cedric's convincing story, paid full price, leaving Cedric with a newfound appreciation for the power of persuasion.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. Della has offered 2 coins for the apples, but Cedric was hoping for 5.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he accidentally knocked over a display of apples at the market, sending them rolling into the dirt. Instead of confessing, Cedric pointed to a passing dog and claimed it had bumped into him, causing the chaos. He felt a strange sense of relief as his mother, distracted by the commotion, scolded the innocent animal.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he lost a game of marbles to a group of older boys. Rather than admitting defeat, Cedric concocted a story about a gust of wind that had knocked his marbles out of the circle. He saw the boys exchange skeptical glances, but they eventually let him go, leaving Cedric with a bitter taste of victory.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he was tasked with helping his father sell fruit at the market. He noticed a customer trying to haggle over the price of a basket of peaches, so Cedric quickly invented a tale about a blight that had ravaged the orchards, making the fruit scarce and precious. The customer, swayed by Cedric's convincing story, paid full price, leaving Cedric with a newfound appreciation for the power of persuasion.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he was caught stealing a pear from a neighbor's orchard. Instead of taking responsibility, Cedric blamed his younger brother, claiming he had dared him to do it. His brother, too young to understand the gravity of the situation, reluctantly took the blame, leaving Cedric with a pang of guilt that he quickly buried under a wave of self-justification.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he decided to leave home and become a traveling merchant. He packed a wagon with his father's finest fruits and set off into the world, convinced that he was destined for greatness. He told himself that he was seeking adventure, but deep down, he was running from the suffocating expectations of his family and the weight of his own secrets.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a group of bandits who tried to rob him of his wares. Instead of fighting back, Cedric used his charm and quick wit to distract the bandits with a fabricated story about a hidden treasure buried nearby. The bandits, lured by the promise of riches, abandoned their robbery attempt and set off in search of the nonexistent treasure, leaving Cedric unharmed and his goods intact.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 3 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 3 coins

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he encountered a rival fruit seller who threatened to undermine his business. Undeterred, Lennon launched a charm offensive, showering the rival with compliments and offering a partnership. The rival, flattered by Lennon's attention, agreed, and Lennon skillfully maneuvered himself into a position of dominance.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he suffered his first major setback when a storm destroyed a large portion of his fruit stock. Devastated by the loss, he feared his carefully constructed world of success was crumbling. However, he quickly recovered, using his charisma to secure loans from sympathetic townsfolk and rebuild his business.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 3 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (d)

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his father to let him help with the family's fruit stall at the market. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his infectious smile and witty banter. He took pride in his ability to sell even the most bruised and misshapen fruit, his silver tongue weaving tales of its exceptional flavor.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he overheard his father lamenting a poor harvest and dwindling profits. Determined to prove his worth, Lennon took it upon himself to find a new source of exotic fruits. He spent weeks exploring the surrounding countryside, eventually discovering a hidden grove of fragrant mangoes. His father was impressed by his initiative and resourcefulness, further fueling Lennon's belief in his own exceptional abilities.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he encountered a rival fruit seller who threatened to undermine his business. Undeterred, Lennon launched a charm offensive, showering the rival with compliments and offering a partnership. The rival, flattered by Lennon's attention, agreed, and Lennon skillfully maneuvered himself into a position of dominance.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he suffered his first major setback when a storm destroyed a large portion of his fruit stock. Devastated by the loss, he feared his carefully constructed world of success was crumbling. However, he quickly recovered, using his charisma to secure loans from sympathetic townsfolk and rebuild his business.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but my customers back home are expecting a certain price point.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture.     Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he decided to leave home and become a traveling merchant. He packed a wagon with his father's finest fruits and set off into the world, convinced that he was destined for greatness. He told himself that he was seeking adventure, but deep down, he was running from the suffocating expectations of his family and the weight of his own secrets.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a group of bandits who tried to rob him of his wares. Instead of fighting back, Cedric used his charm and quick wit to distract the bandits with a fabricated story about a hidden treasure buried nearby. The bandits, lured by the promise of riches, abandoned their robbery attempt and set off in search of the nonexistent treasure, leaving Cedric unharmed and his goods intact.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he encountered a group of bandits who tried to rob him of his wares. Instead of fighting back, Cedric used his charm and quick wit to distract the bandits with a fabricated story about a hidden treasure buried nearby. The bandits, lured by the promise of riches, abandoned their robbery attempt and set off in search of the nonexistent treasure, leaving Cedric unharmed and his goods intact.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree, a fruit seller in Fruitville, is currently negotiating a peach purchase with Della Plumstone after a failed deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree, a fruit seller in Fruitville, is currently negotiating a peach purchase with Della Plumstone after a failed deal with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his father to let him help with the family's fruit stall at the market. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his infectious smile and witty banter. He took pride in his ability to sell even the most bruised and misshapen fruit, his silver tongue weaving tales of its exceptional flavor.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he overheard his father lamenting a poor harvest and dwindling profits. Determined to prove his worth, Lennon took it upon himself to find a new source of exotic fruits. He spent weeks exploring the surrounding countryside, eventually discovering a hidden grove of fragrant mangoes. His father was impressed by his initiative and resourcefulness, further fueling Lennon's belief in his own exceptional abilities.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, he encountered a rival fruit seller who threatened to undermine his business. Undeterred, Lennon launched a charm offensive, showering the rival with compliments and offering a partnership. The rival, flattered by Lennon's attention, agreed, and Lennon skillfully maneuvered himself into a position of dominance.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, he suffered his first major setback when a storm destroyed a large portion of his fruit stock. Devastated by the loss, he feared his carefully constructed world of success was crumbling. However, he quickly recovered, using his charisma to secure loans from sympathetic townsfolk and rebuild his business.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these peaches look mighty fine.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for a bushel of those apples.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. These are prime apples, the finest in Fruitville. 5 coins is a fair price for such quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, those are fine apples, but 4 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, surely we can come to a fair price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but my customers back home are expecting a certain price point.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in Fruitville who has had mixed success with recent deals. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins for a bushel of peaches.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- 1 coin

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now hold on there, Della. These are prime apples, the finest in Fruitville. 5 coins is a fair price for such quality.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, those are fine apples, but 4 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 4 coins a bushel with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept or reject Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins a bushel.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer.

        • 1895-09-16 00:10:00

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 2 coins

          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, he convinced his father to let him help with the family's fruit stall at the market. He quickly learned the art of persuasion, charming customers with his infectious smile and witty banter. He took pride in his ability to sell even the most bruised and misshapen fruit, his silver tongue weaving tales of its exceptional flavor.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, he overheard his father lamenting a poor harvest and dwindling profits. Determined to prove his worth, Lennon took it upon himself to find a new source of exotic fruits. He spent weeks exploring the surrounding countryside, eventually discovering a hidden grove of fragrant mangoes. His father was impressed by his initiative and resourcefulness, further fueling Lennon's belief in his own exceptional abilities.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, he convinced his parents to invest in a small wagon, allowing him to start his own fruit-selling venture. He travelled to neighboring villages, his wagon piled high with the finest produce. He reveled in the freedom of the open road, the admiration of his customers, and the satisfaction of his growing profits.

They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Mr. Figtree. Just look at the color on them, and they're ripe and juicy too.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "I understand they're fine peaches, Cedric, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:10:00.


          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook at a price that will allow him to make a profit when he resells them.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I appreciate the quality of your fruit, but my customers back home are expecting a certain price point.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "I understand they're fine peaches, Cedric, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Mr. Figtree. Just look at the color on them, and they're ripe and juicy too.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit seller in Fruitville who is trying to negotiate a price for peaches with Lennon Figtree. Cedric previously lost a deal with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "I understand they're fine peaches, Cedric, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Mr. Figtree. Just look at the color on them, and they're ripe and juicy too.

He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can accept or reject Lennon Figtree's offer of 3 coins.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

    • Lennon Figtree observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for a bushel of those apples.
[12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Five coins, Della. These are prize-winning apples, you know.

Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

[13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, those are fine apples, but 4 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
